data.text: Flat Bars or Drop Bars on a Gravel Bike?

Hello guys , it might be a impossible question to be answered bc it relates to personal preference but I’ll still ask ,flat bars or drop bars for a gravel bike ? Where I Live I don’t have much hard gravel or single tracks , so I’ll be doing most pavement to get to some light gravel but the plan is to travel from time to time and hit some more gravel paths at nearby states from me, I live in Massachusetts. So for the ones that rode both flat and drop bars , which one would you go for ?

I have tried for years to like drop bars on my gravel bike. I finally gave up and realized I just don't like them. I like Jones or Moloko bars. I guess my mountain background just won't let me like drop bars.
data.author: Chris Owens

data.text: thx !!
data.author: Joaquim Oliveira

data.text: I started with mtb...got a drop bar gravel bike after a few yrs, hated drop bars (doesn't help that I have really short fingers and no amount of adjusting would help). Sold it for a straight bar gravel bike.
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: Drops for sure
data.author: Andrew Huff

data.text: I do mostly road followed by gravel. So drops were an easy “adjustment” on gravel. I like the variety of positions that drops provide. Unless you need super upright positions, I go with flared drops every time!
data.author: Shawn Lewis

data.text: Personal preference... ride what you like. Personally, I ride drop bars, because I find them to be just fine for road, gravel or light single track (frequently clip-on aero bars for road/gravel). Flat bars are for more technical stuff and stay on my MTB.
data.author: Drew Downing

data.text: Personal preference to be sure. That said... Drop bars. But something like a Red Shift Kitchen Sink or a Ritchey Venture Max... they give you a lot of options for hand positions. Also shallow drop with flare and a little bit of rise and sweep.
data.author: Joe Viger

data.text: Depends on riding style an terrain. Flats are better for casual pace, or more technical terrain or singletrack. Drops are better for longer rides at a more spirited pace, less tech. I like my wide, short reach shallow drop flared bars.
data.author: Philip Rohrer

data.text: I bought a used checkpoint that had been converted to a flat bar set up. I bought it fully intending to convert it back. Just for fun I wanted to try the flat bars and here’s my opinion: I hated it. It just didn’t feel right to me at all. It felt like ot screwed up the geometry of the bike. I’m an old mtb guy so have lots of experience with flat bars. So that’s my 2 cents
data.author: Mike Wilson

data.text: Drop bars for me!
data.author: Paul Lindley

data.text: I ride road, MTB and gravel, and I say definitely some variety of drop bar (or maybe multi-position flat bar) for gravel. I’ve found it’s essential to be able to switch up hand positions as conditions change or you fatigue.
data.author: David Watson

data.text: I have both, flat bars on my mtn bike, drop bars on road and gravel bikes. I personally like the hand location options on drop bars (drops, hoods, tops). Only one hand location on flat bars.
data.author: Don Mann

data.text: yeah the multiple hand positions are big on long rides for sure. You can get that with “alt bars” as well but I still enjoy the very aggressive, head first, down-in-the-drops position for smooth, fast descents!
data.author: Ken Sears

data.text: i like drops. i have other bikes with straight bars but i mostly ride my bikes with drops
data.author: Steven Tong

data.text: Drops, 3 hand positions.
data.author: Peter Hoppe

data.text: Well... Personal Preference, drop bars. I prefer to be able to go in narrow passages with the drop bars. And when riding on the hoods it is not that different "posture" position than flat bars.
data.author: Andre Velloso

data.text: I perfer Alt Bars like the Jones Loop or surly corner bars. These will allow you to ride with comfort, more hand positions and more cost effective when it comes to groupsets if you want to swap those out.
data.author: Mauricio Montejano

data.text: I run an alt bar on my MTB. And wide sweeped drops on my CX bike. (Surly Moloko/Ritchey Comp Beacon)
data.author: Jordan Nickel

data.text: I’ll do that I think , get an alt bar .
data.author: Joaquim Oliveira

data.text: if you like hanging stuff off your bar id get a moloko/jones bar. if you just want a more "aero" drop like position (like i wanted) get the veloorange crazy bar. i think that would be alot more comfortable than the moloko
data.author: Jordan Nickel

data.text: thx a lot , just went to the veloorange website , great !!! Now I’ll buy a flatbar and change to a crazy bar
data.author: Joaquim Oliveira

data.text: I’ve got 3 gravel bikes, one with flat bars, the other 2 with drops. So far I’m not a huge fan of the flats, except when it’s time to hit a steep punchy climb. I haven’t ridden a double century on that bike yet, but I’m fairly certain it’s going to destroy my hands, even with Ergon grips.
data.author: Justin M Short BA

data.text: I prefer flared drops - to me the whole point is being able to ride everything from fast road / gravel road to techy singletrails…with flat bars you completely miss out on the „fast“ aspect on roads and compact gravel roads…
data.author: Jnc Mrc

data.text: Flat bars for trails, drop bars for roads. Gravel is roads.
data.author: Brett Jensen

data.text: Curly
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: I find that I only use the flat section and the hoods on my drop bar bikes...I rarely ever use the hoods. Maybe if I'm trying to tuck on a fast downhill but honestly...I can tuck just as well without the drops. I'm seriously thinking about building up a frame that I have hanging up on the wall in my garage and turning it into a flat bar gravel bike...might even try something like the Surly Corner bars or at least some sort of swept flat bar or even bull horns. But I'm pretty sure I'm done with drops.
data.author: Chad Ashton

data.text: Drop bar is gravel bike Flat bat is mtb No?..
data.author: Tony Ho

data.text: I prefer drop bars. However, the Surly Corner bars are a good mix between the two.
data.author: Michele Bernhard

data.text: Drop bars would be my choice, but gravel specific- wide, shallow and flared.
data.author: Chris Summers

data.text: I like drop bars , give you more options
data.author: David Riley

data.text: Thx to everyone that gave me a suggestion, I’ll get the flat bar version and later on look for some Alt bars . Thx again guys !!!!
data.author: Joaquim Oliveira

data.text: I now ride exclusively flat bars. If you want to know why I like flat bars over drop bars for gravel riding I'd be happy to share.
data.author: Ian Ramsey

data.text: My gravel routes have a lot of singletrack and off-road so flat bar for me atm is better.100mm stem slammed, flipped and flat headset cup. 50cm bar 15mm rise tiny bit of backsweep. Have 110mm stem on the way 🤙

data.text: thing is a weapon.

data.author: Q Scott Quinney

data.text: Go for flat bars
data.author: Aakash Sethi

data.text: After just a few weeks with the drop bars on my gravel bike, I would never go back to flatties. Personal choice I guess.
